tutorial: pyg.base¶

pyg.base contains some functionality to make your life easier:

  • dt, drange and dt_bump functionality (with calendar) will make your dates manipulation much easier

  • encode/decode of data will allow you to send to json or to MongoDB seemlessly

  • eq, zipper, reducer

  • text utilities

However, there are two areas where pyg.base can really change the way you write code.

  • Dict, dictable, perdictable

  • cell

Dict¶

There are a few libraries allowing members access of a dict via getattr.

>>> from pyg import *
>>> import yfinance as yf
>>> d = Dict(a = 1, b = 2)
>>> assert d.a == 1

Dict also makes it easier to add new members and remove them

>>> assert Dict(a = 1)(b = 2)(c = 3) == Dict(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)
>>> assert Dict(a = 1)(b = 2) + dict(c = 3) == Dict(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)

But the fun part is when Dict allows ‘access’ to function of its members

>>> d = Dict(a = 1, b = 2)
>>> assert d[lambda a, b: a+b] == 3
>>> d = d(c = lambda a, b: a+b)
>>> assert d == Dict(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)

This means we can think of a Dict as a container of variables. Consider this code:

>>> def func(a, b):
>>>     c = a + b
>>>     d = b + c
>>>     e = a/b + d/c
>>>     f = (d+e)/c
>>>     return f
>>> func(1,2)

How can we keep track of our calculations and debug it easily? Consider rewriting this:

>>> x = Dict(a = 1, b = 2)
>>> x = x(c = lambda a, b: a + b)
>>> x = x(d = lambda b, c: b + c)
>>> x = x(e = lambda a,b,c,d : a/b + d/c)
>>> x = x(f = lambda c,d,e: (d+e)/c)
>>> assert x.f == func(x.a, x.b)

The nice thing is that we have all the internals of the function exposed too. We are able to separate code and data easily:

>>> code = dict(c = lambda a, b: a + b,
>>>             d = lambda b, c: b + c,
>>>             e = lambda a,b,c,d : a/b + d/c,
>>>             f = lambda c,d,e: (d+e)/c)

>>> initial_values = Dict(a = 1, b = 2)
>>> final_output = initial_values(**code)

dictable¶

Dict was fun but that if we can run this not just for a single record, but for multiple ones?

>>> x = dictable(a = [1,2,3], b = [4,5,6])

We now run an identical code:

>>> x = x(**code)

And get each of the rows evaluated

>>> x
>>> dictable[3 x 6]
>>> a|b|c|d |e                 |f
>>> 1|4|5|9 |2.05              |2.21
>>> 2|5|7|12|2.1142857142857143|2.0163265306122446
>>> 3|6|9|15|2.166666666666667 |1.9074074074074074
